items.title: Ukraine’s Dilemma as Pokrovsk Teeters: Save Lives or Keep Holding On
items.summary: Military analysts and some Ukrainian commanders worry that Kyiv may be repeating the mistake of staying in an embattled city longer than it should, aiming to inflict far more casualties than it suffers.

items.title: Family of Fisherman Killed in U.S. Military Strike Says It Wants Justice
items.summary: Colombia was a top U.S. ally in Latin America until the Trump administration began deadly strikes in international waters. Now, one family wants justice.

items.title: How Pakistan’s Spending Blitz Helped Win Over Trump and Flip U.S. Policy
items.summary: As Pakistan has hired lobbyists with close ties to President Trump, it has also received favorable tariff treatment and unique access in Washington.

items.title: In the Faroe Islands’ Soccer Team, the Players Also Have Day Jobs
items.summary: The Faroe Islands, rugged green specks in the North Atlantic, are an underdog. Most of the guys on the team have day jobs.

items.title: How France Remembers the November 2015 Terrorist Attacks in Paris
items.summary: A decade ago, Islamic State militants killed 130 people in an assault that shocked France. Some survivors are still struggling, but for many of their compatriots, memories of the attacks are growing more distant.

items.title: Israeli Settlers Burn West Bank Mosque Amid Rise in Violent Attacks
items.summary: Since the 2023 attack on Israel by Hamas, growing settler violence and Israeli attacks on Palestinian militants have thrown the West Bank into turmoil and displaced tens of thousands.

items.title: Former Prince Andrew and Another Prominent Briton Come Up in the Epstein Emails
items.summary: Newly released files from Jeffrey Epstein include correspondence with Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor and Peter Mandelson, the former British ambassador to Washington.

items.title: What Our Photographer Saw as a Safe City Became a Blood Bath
items.summary: The Ukrainian city of Pokrovsk is on the verge of becoming another shattered trophy for the Russian Army.

items.title: China’s ‘Wolf Warrior’ Diplomacy Returns With Threat Against Japan’s Leader
items.summary: A Chinese diplomat’s call to cut off the prime minister’s “filthy head” signaled a revival of a combative style Beijing had tried to dial back.

items.title: Gustavo Petro, the Rebel Turned President Willing to Take on Trump
items.summary: From his guerrilla roots, Colombia’s president, Gustavo Petro, has long embraced a confrontational style. Now, he has incurred President Trump’s wrath and is facing political fallout at home.

items.title: Juan Ponce Enrile, a Political Power in the Philippines, Dies at 101
items.summary: A protégé of Ferdinand Marcos, he helped administer martial law for eight years before turning on his patron in the “People Power” uprising of 1986.

items.title: Fake Bomb Threats Baffle the Police Across Asia
items.summary: The threatening emails and faxes bear the signature of a man who says he is being impersonated. The police in five nations have failed to stem them.

items.title: Man Accused of Running Southeast Asia Scam Compound Is Extradited to China
items.summary: China and the United States say She Zhijiang, a Chinese-born businessman, ran a major scam compound in Myanmar. He was arrested in Bangkok in 2022.

items.title: Some South Korean Workers Return to Georgia Factory After U.S. Reissues Visas
items.summary: The State Department has reissued visas for many workers detained in a September raid, lawyers said, as the Trump administration tries to undo damage from the operation.

items.title: BBC Apologizes to Trump Over Film Edit but Declines to Pay Compensation
items.summary: The BBC said it would not rebroadcast a misleadingly edited documentary but added, “We strongly disagree there is a basis for a defamation claim.”

items.title: Of Books and Men
items.summary: My colleague, the book critic Dwight Garner, tells us about “Flesh” by David Szalay, this year’s Booker Prize winner.

items.title: U.S. Officials Raise Concerns About Saudi Arabia’s Bid for F-35 Jets
items.summary: A Pentagon intelligence report says China could try to acquire advanced F-35 technology in Saudi Arabia if the Trump administration sells jets to the kingdom.

items.title: The Global Climate Leadership Vacuum
items.summary: The United States is largely absent from the United Nations climate negations in Brazil. So who is stepping up?

items.title: An Ontario Man Took a Bus for a Joyride. Turns Out, He’s Not a Bad Driver.
items.summary: The incident in Hamilton, Ontario, ended safely with an arrest and no injuries (and all fares paid).

items.title: Bird Flu Ravaged the World’s Largest Elephant Seal Population, Study Finds
items.summary: After the H5N1 virus hit the remote island of South Georgia in 2023, more than 50,000 breeding females may have disappeared.

items.title: He Helped Cities Anticipate Damage From Storms
items.summary: Austin Becker developed an early warning system to protect critical infrastructure from storms. His project’s funding was eliminated in April.

items.title: Rubio Shrugs Off Allies’ Concerns Over U.S. Drug Strikes
items.summary: Secretary of State Marco Rubio said no one raised the Caribbean military operation in closed-door meetings at a G7 summit. But ministers from France and the European Union publicly called them unlawful.

items.title: Greenhouse Gas Emissions Head for a Record in 2025, Global Carbon Project Reports
items.summary: But there are signs that greenhouse gas pollution in China might be slowing, according to a new analysis.

items.title: Former Syrian Security Official Indicted in Austria
items.summary: Prosecutors say a Syrian security official accused of torture hid in plain sight in Europe for years, protected by Israeli and Austrian intelligence agents.

items.title: Iraq’s Prime Minister Leads in Elections but May Struggle to Form a Government
items.summary: Mohammed al-Sudani pitches himself as someone who can keep Iranian influence in check, but his vote share may not be big enough to ensure a clear political victory.

items.title: South Asia on Edge
items.summary: There are no known links between two bomb attacks in India and Pakistan, but they come as tensions between the countries are already high.

items.title: As Belgium Races to Save U.S.A.I.D. Contraception, Some Supplies Are Reported Ruined
items.summary: The Belgian government is in talks with the Trump administration to save birth control stranded in a warehouse, but another shipment has been incorrectly stored.

items.title: Algeria Pardons Writer Boualem Sansal at Germany’s Request
items.summary: Boualem Sansal, an Algerian-French writer, was arrested on accusations of undermining national security during a visit to his homeland a year ago and sentenced to five years in prison.

items.title: Labour Party’s Internal Fight Goes Public, as Starmer’s Trouble Grows
items.summary: An attempt by Keir Starmer’s allies to undercut a rival has forced into the open a party debate over whether to replace the prime minister.

items.title: Many Displaced Sudanese Feared Dead After Shipwreck Near Libya
items.summary: Forty-two migrants were presumed dead after a rubber boat capsized off the Libyan coast this month. Many of the presumed victims were fleeing a raging conflict in Sudan.

items.title: How to Capture the Northern Lights With Just Your Smartphone
items.summary: Modern cellphone cameras make it easy to capture the famously fickle Aurora Borealis.

items.title: Israel Reopens Gaza Aid Route It Had Closed for Months
items.summary: The cease-fire with Hamas has blunted the hunger faced by Gazans during the war. But aid agencies say Israeli restrictions are still hobbling their work.

items.title: Pakistan’s Army Chief Is Granted Sweeping Authority Over All Military Branches
items.summary: A constitutional amendment in the nuclear-armed country extends the chief’s power over all the military and brings Pakistan’s highest court under tighter political control.

items.title: Deadly Blasts in India and Pakistan Set Region on Edge
items.summary: The rare explosions in the country’s capitals have not been directly linked, but there are fears the governments will blame each other after their previous military conflict alarmed the world.

items.title: Blue Diamond Sells for $25.6 Million at Auction in Switzerland
items.summary: A 9.51-carat blue stone that once belonged to the heiress Bunny Mellon sold for $7 million less than at its last auction, a sign of profound shifts in the diamond industry.

items.title: Japan’s Prime Minister Faces Backlash Over 3 A.M. Staff Meeting
items.summary: Sanae Takaichi drew criticism for requiring staff to work in the wee hours in a country scarred by “death from overwork.”

items.title: Syria’s Leaders Pledge to Join Fight Against Islamic State
items.summary: Large parts of Syria were once overrun by the terrorist group Islamic State. The country’s new government has just committed to a global effort to fight the group.

items.title: Blood and Tears as Spain’s Troubled Bullfighting Star Hangs Up His Cape
items.summary: José Antonio Morante Camacho says he has fought his last bull. Fans appreciated his artistry but also his honesty about his struggles with mental illness.

items.title: A Look Into the Early Days of Migrant Detentions at Guantánamo
items.summary: Government employees distributed Bibles and prepared materials “commonly used in Hinduism, Sikhism and Rastafarianism,” according to emails.

items.title: The ‘Lost Sisters’ of the Pleiades Fill the Entire Night Sky
items.summary: Astronomers identified more than 3,000 stars associated with the cluster, and there might be even more.

items.title: Turkish Military Plane Crashes in Georgia, Killing 20 Troops
items.summary: The Turkish defense minister said that 20 Air Force servicemen died when their military cargo plane crashed after taking off from Azerbaijan on Tuesday.

items.title: How a New Bridge Partly Collapsed in China’s Southwest
items.summary: A section of the tall bridge in mountainous Sichuan Province fell, apparently after a landslide. No casualties were reported.

items.title: Xi’s Military Purges Show Unease About China’s Nuclear Forces
items.summary: The shake-up in China’s armed forces comes as both Beijing and Washington are pushing through major changes in their country’s militaries, in different ways.

items.title: There’s a New Forecast for Peak Oil Demand. It’s Increasingly Cloudy.
items.summary: The International Energy Agency once projected that oil and gas demand could level off by 2030. Now it’s backing off, sort of.

items.title: What It Takes to Move a Factory From China to Vietnam
items.summary: Tariffs have forced Chinese companies to move their operations to Vietnam. Alexandra Stevenson, our Shanghai bureau chief, visits a factory in Ho Chi Minh City to see how one of the biggest challenges isn’t relocating machinery and tools, but overcoming language barriers.

items.title: Newsom in the Spotlight at the Climate Conference That Trump Decided to Skip
items.summary: The California governor painted the president as a threat to American competitiveness by letting China dominate the renewable energy industry.

items.title: Key Netanyahu Minister Steps Down From Israel’s Government
items.summary: Ron Dermer, a longtime ally of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and an influential figure in the Israeli government throughout the war in Gaza, resigned as minister of strategic affairs.

items.title: Senator Criticizes Rubio for Paying $7.5 Million to Equatorial Guinea to Take Deportees
items.summary: Senator Jeanne Shaheen, Democrat of New Hampshire, said the African country has a long history of corruption. The amount paid is far more than recent annual assistance given to it.

items.title: Israel Arrests 4 After Jewish Extremist Attack in West Bank
items.summary: Dozens of masked Israelis attacked an industrial zone, torching vehicles and wounding Palestinians, according to Palestinian officials.

items.title: Women in Power, and on the Right
items.summary: Two G7 countries now have female leaders, and they have something in common.

items.title: Trump Threatened to Sue the BBC for $1 Billion. What Are His Chances?
items.summary: Legal experts say President Trump’s litigation track record offers both hope and warning to the British public broadcaster, which he has threatened with a $1 billion suit.

items.title: Turkey Seeks Jail Sentence of Over 2,000 Years for Istanbul Mayor Ekrem Imamoglu
items.summary: Prosecutors accused Ekrem Imamoglu, the mayor of Istanbul, of leading a criminal organization. The opposition called the case politically motivated.

items.title: Trump Is Said to Propose Opening California Coast to Oil Drilling
items.summary: Gov. Gavin Newsom, a chief critic of the president and an opponent of oil exploration in the Pacific, called the proposal “dead on arrival.”

items.title: Roman-Era Treasures Stolen From Syria’s National Museum
items.summary: The Damascus museum theft set off an official investigation in what may be one of Syria’s largest losses of antiquities in recent years.

items.title: The Mysterious ‘Louvre Detective’ Was a 15-Year-Old Passer-by
items.summary: The photo of a dapper man in a fedora sparked many questions: Was the person real? A Sherlock Holmes-inspired detective on the case? Or just being very French?
